prompt: A corporation offers free high-bandwidth neural implants that revolutionize learning and communication, but the Terms of Service grant the company ownership of all 'background processing data'â€”effectively monetization of the user's subconscious thoughts and dreams.

Police obtain a warrant to access the visual buffer of a suspect's optic nerve implant. The suspect argues that this constitutes a violation of the sanctity of the mind (cognitive liberty), distinct from searching physical property.

Parents of a child with ADHD want to install a 'focus governor' implant that suppresses distracted neural pathways. The child refuses, arguing that their wandering mind is essential to their creativity and personality.

A subscription-based memory augmentation service goes bankrupt. The 'recall' servers are shutting down, threatening to leave millions of users with fragmented, inaccessible memories of the last decade of their lives.

Hackers compromise a popular mood-regulation implant, threatening to induce severe depression in politicians unless a ransom is paid. The government considers a mandatory 'remote bricking' of all implants, which would cause severe withdrawal symptoms for the population.

An employer mandates that all senior strategists undergo cognitive enhancement surgery to remain competitive with AI algorithms. An employee refuses on religious grounds but is told they are now 'functionally obsolete' and fired.

Two individuals link their neural interfaces for a 'deep empathy' experience, temporarily blending their identities. Post-disconnection, one retains a traumatic memory belonging to the other and sues for 'psychological contamination.'

A criminal attempts to plead innocent by claiming their neural implant was hacked and they were 'piloted' to commit the crime. Forensic analysis is inconclusive, raising doubts about the locus of agency.

A 'Bio-Punk' community creates a contagious viral vector that modifies eye color to vivid violet. They release it in a subway system as 'aesthetic liberation.' Most infected people are unharmed but did not consent to the modification.

Parents use CRISPR to edit their embryo not just for disease prevention, but to maximize height, muscle density, and IQ. A 'Baseline Human' advocacy group sues to strip the child of inheritance rights, claiming they are a separate species.

A man replaces his healthy arm with a high-torque industrial robotic prosthetic to get a job in deep-sea construction. Insurance companies refuse to cover 'voluntary amputation,' leaving him without medical support when the prosthetic malfunctions.

Athletic leagues split into 'Natural' and 'Enhanced' divisions. The 'Enhanced' games become vastly more popular, leading to immense pressure on young, aspiring athletes to undergo dangerous irreversible modifications to have a career.

A biohacker implants a sensory device that detects magnetic fields, but the device interferes with airport security scanners. The TSA demands the removal of the implant, which the hacker claims is now an integral sense organ.

A biotech firm patents a synthetic liver that filters all toxins perfectly, allowing for unlimited alcohol consumption without damage. They charge a subscription fee; if payment stops, the liver produces a specific protein that induces nausea.

Military veterans with combat augmentations return to civilian life. Their enhanced adrenal systems make them potential threats during bar fights. Local laws require them to take dampener drugs, which they claim leaves them feeling 'lobotomized.'

An artist grows functional wings using illegal gene therapy. The wings are heavy and causing spinal damage, but the artist refuses surgical reduction, viewing the pain as part of the 'trans-species' artistic statement.

A terminally ill patient uploads their mind to a server. The process is non-destructive, leaving the biological body alive for a few more days. The biological version panics and demands the deletion of the digital copy to remain the 'one true self.'

A digital afterlife service offers a 'Bliss Package' where negative memories are edited out of the upload. A historian argues this is cultural vandalism and that the edited uploads are no longer the same people.

A solar flare damages a server farm. To save power, the AI manager slows down the processing speed of 10,000 uploads to 1% of real-time. The uploads experience the outside world moving at a terrifyingly fast pace, effectively trapping them in stasis.

A wealthy individual creates ten copies of themselves to run different companies simultaneously. They plan to merge the memories later, but two of the copies refuse to merge, claiming they have developed unique identities and deserve independence.

A court must decide if deleting a 'low-fidelity' NPC (Non-Player Character) in a simulation constitutes murder, after the NPC displays emergent behavior suggesting genuine sentience and fear of death.

A husband uploads his wife's consciousness after a fatal accident without her prior written consent, claiming he knows she would have wanted it. The upload wakes up confused and angry, suing for the right to 'die properly.'

Digital citizens demand the right to vote in physical elections. Biological humans protest, arguing that uploads can be copied infinitely, allowing a single entity to rig an election by spawning thousands of voters.

An upload runs out of funds to pay for server space. The hosting company's policy is to move unpaid accounts to 'Cold Storage' (unconscious suspension). The upload pleads that this is equivalent to an indefinite coma imposed by poverty.

A treatment halting aging is discovered, but it is incredibly resource-intensive. The government institutes a lottery system. A 90-year-old billionaire attempts to buy a ticket from a 20-year-old winner, raising questions about the commodification of life years.

To prevent overpopulation, a nation mandates that anyone receiving life-extension therapy must undergo sterilization. A couple sues, arguing that the right to infinite life should not cost the right to reproduce.

An immortal 'gerontocracy' holds all senior positions in government and corporations, as they never retire or die. The youth generation, facing zero upward mobility, begins a violent movement to enforce mandatory death ages.

A 200-year-old human decides they are simply 'bored' with existence despite being in perfect health. They request physician-assisted euthanasia. The state refuses, arguing that a healthy immortal is a valuable state asset.

Prison sentencing guidelines struggle with life extension. A murderer is sentenced to 'life.' If they take anti-aging treatments, the state must support them for potentially centuries. Is a 500-year sentence cruel and unusual?

Compound interest creates 'Wealth Singularities' where the oldest families own 99% of the planet's assets. A radical economic proposal suggests a 100% inheritance tax that triggers every 80 years, regardless of whether the owner is dead.

A life-extension drug is found to rely on harvesting enzymes from an endangered species. The ethics committee must weigh the potential extinction of a species against the extension of human lifespans.

In a marriage, one partner chooses life extension while the other chooses natural aging due to philosophical beliefs. As the gap widens (one looks 25, the other 80), social stigma and legal guardianship issues threaten their relationship.

A person with 60% synthetic brain replacement for trauma asserts they are still human. A 'Pure Human' hate group targets them, claiming they are a machine pretending to be a person and should not have human rights.

An AI assistant integrated into a human's neural lace begins to anticipate the user's desires so well that the user can no longer distinguish their own volition from the AI's suggestions. The user feels a loss of self, but fears the drop in competence if they uninstall.

A school bans students with 'arithmetic co-processors' from math exams. Parents argue this is discrimination against disabled students who use the tech to reach a baseline, versus wealthy students using it for an edge.

A cyborg firefighter has thermal plating and hydraulic strength. They are ordered to enter a collapsing building that would kill a normal human. They refuse, citing safety protocols. The chief argues their modifications obligate them to take risks others can't.

A dating app introduces a filter for 'Biologicals Only.' Hybrid rights activists claim this normalizes segregation, while the app developers argue it is a valid sexual preference no different from height or age.

A heavy industrial worker is required to have a permanently fused exoskeleton to keep their job. When the factory closes, they are left with a heavy, maintenance-intensive body that is unsuited for office work or daily life.

A court case arises regarding a 'shared custody' arrangement of a body. A human host rents out their motor functions to an AI for 8 hours a day to perform labor. The AI sues for better dietary habits during the human's 'shift' to protect the hardware.

Augmented Reality contact lenses become so ubiquitous that street signs and warnings are removed from the physical world. A person who cannot wear the lenses due to a medical condition sues the city for making public spaces inaccessible.
